Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of a Flipped Classroom Model in Nursing Education

Trial_Design.evidence: A total of 228 participants were randomised

Participants.evidence: The study was conducted at the University of Ruse, Bulgaria, with eligibility criteria including enrollment in the nursing or midwifery program.

Intervention.evidence: control group receiving traditional instruction and an experimental group engaged in a digitally enhanced preparatory phase.

Objective.evidence: This study investigates the effect of a digitally enhanced flipped classroom model on the self-perceived competence of Bulgarian nursing and midwifery students.

Method_Outcome.evidence: A 25-item self-report questionnaire measured perceived competence in injection techniques, hygiene care, midwifery skills, and digital readiness before and after the intervention.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 228 participants were randomised

Result_Outcome.evidence: Statistical analysis using Welch’s t-test revealed significant improvements in the experimental group across all domains (p < 0.001).
